detailed_description.textblock:
Aim / Primary objective:
To elucidate the relationship of chewing miswak sticks on the H. Pylori infection in the oral cavity.
Specific Objectives To find the prevalence of oral H.Pylori among the Saudi Population To compare the reduction in count of oral H. Pylori among tooth brush users and miswak users Secondary Objectives
1) To elucidate the count and type of microbiota present in the tooth brush and miswak after use.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Study Area: The study would be conducted at the College of Dentistry, KSAU-HS, Riyadh, KSA.
Study Subjects:
The study sample would be selected from the regular dental patients visiting the College of Dentistry, KSAU-HS, Saudi Arabia. The inclusion criteria would be: subjects aged >18yrs, having >24 teeth and physically/mentally healthy. Oral plaque samples would be obtained from those patients who are willing to participate. As a part of the initial screening the plaque samples would be collected and sent for screening of oral microbiota to the Microbiology and Biochemistry Department of College of Medicine, KSAU-HS, NGHA, Riyadh. Here, the basic microbial culturing (rapid urease test) would be performed for detecting the presence of oral H.Pylori. Volunteers who are tested positive for H. Pylori infection through the rapid urease test would be invited to participate in the study.
Study Design: This is a single blinded randomized clinical trial.
Data Collection methods, instruments used, measurements:
The subjects would be interviewed and information would be collected on their socio demographic characteristics (Age, gender, socio-economic status, education, occupation), diet, related past medical and dental history.
In addition, oral plaque samples would be sent for 16S rRNA gene sequencing to have the baseline readings.
The main outcome variable would be the change over time of the microbiologic data within both groups. Thus, the change in the number H.Pylori would be compared between the two groups at regular predetermined intervals (end of 1st week, 2nd week, 1st month and 3rd month).
The patients would be recalled regularly and their plaque samples would be collected and sent for 16S rRNA gene sequencing. Gene sequencing has been known to provide more accurate information on the species of Helicobacter when compared to other methods.
Sample collection procedure and Purification of Microbes
The plaque would be sampled from the deepest pocket and removed with a sterile universal curette. If subgingival and supragingival plaques were present, then both would be sampled.
The sampling area would be isolated from saliva and gently dried by air. The point would be then immersed in 0.5 ml sterile distilled water in Eppendorf tubes (epTIPS Standard, Eppendorf AG, Hamburg, Germany).
This will be serially diluted to isolate microbes using spread and pour plating methods. Different morphotypes will be purified and maintained. Culturing would be done using Lactose Broth (LB) or Nutrient Agar (NA) plates. This will provide the baseline count of H.Pylori, which will be helpful to compare with the future counts.
Rapid Unease Test
Initial samples taken for screening of H. pylori would be sent for rapid unease test (Campylobacter-like organism or CLO test).
Plaque sample would be placed into an reconstituted vial and observed for the color change from yellow to red (in case of positive samples) which usually takes less than 60 minutes.
Characterization of pure cultures based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis
In order to identify the bacterial species to the nearest taxa, gene sequencing would be performed.
The 16S rRNA gene would be amplified from genomic DNA, purified and sequenced as described earlier by Shivaji et al. (2000). DNA isolated from pure cultures will be amplified individually using a set of primers complementary to the conserved regions of both 5' and 3' ends of 16S rRNA gene (Lane 1991). The forward and reverse primers that would be used are: 5'- GAGTTTGATCCTGGCTCAG-3' and 5'-ACGGCTACCT-TGTTACGACTT- 3', respectively.
The PCR would be was performed in 50 μL reaction mixture containing 2.5 units Taq DNA polymerase (Takara Bio, Kyoto, Japan), 1 X PCR buffer with 1.5 mmol/L MgCl2, 200 μmol/L each deoxynucleotide, 0.2 μmol/L each primer, and 10 μL template DNA. PCR would be performed in Mastercycler ep Eppendorf thermo cycler (Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany) with the following conditions: initial denaturation for 1 min at 95°C was followed by 25 cycles of 94°C for 1 min, 52°C for 30 s, 72°C for 1 min with a possible extension of 7 min at 72°C.The reaction products viewed under ultraviolet light. After screening in gel the PCR product would be sequenced using the two primers given above and also the following set of five forward and two reverse primers.
The forward primers: TAACACATGCAAGTCGAACG (50-70); CTACGGGAGGC-AGCAGTGGG (341-361); CAGCAGCCGCGGTAATAC (518-536); AAACTCAAAG-GAATTGACGG (908-928) and CATGGCTGTCGTCAGCTCGT (1053-1073) and the reverse primers GTATTACCGCGGCTGCTG (536-518) and ACGAGCTGACGACA-GCCATG (1073-1053) were selected to amplify total 1.5 KB 16S rRNA gene. All the will be sequenced on an ABI 3730xl DNA Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, CA). The numbers given in parentheses refer to the nucleotide positions of the primers corresponding to those in the 16S rDNA of Escherichia coli (Hwang, Kim et al. 2011), The 16S rRNA gene sequences obtained will be subjected to BLAST sequence similarity search to identify the nearest taxa.
Data management and analysis plan
The data would be analyzed with SPSS for Windows 17.0 (IBM SPSS, Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).
After the completion of data entry, data would be checked for errors. The chi-square test would be used to analyze the demographic differences in the two groups. ANOVA would be applied to assess the differences in the various variables. The Tukey-Kramer Multiple Comparisons test would be used for continuous data, whereas Fisher's exact test would be used for comparing the frequencies of categorical variables.
Ethical Considerations:
This study would seek the approval from the Ethical Committee, College of Dentistry, King Saud Bin Abdul-Aziz University for Health Sciences (KSAU-HS) and Ethical Committee of King Abdullah International Medical Research Center (KAIMRC). Investigators having direct patient contact Would be sensitized according to the International Conference of Harmonization's Good Clinical Practice (ICH-GCP). Before the study, participants would be informed about the study objectives and their signed informed consent would be obtained.
